newsitem.title: BOSNIA: U.S. awards $23.6 million for energy in Bosnia.
newsitem.headline: U.S. awards $23.6 million for energy in Bosnia.

text.p: The United States on Friday awarded $23.6 million to Bosnia to rehabilitate an important power plant and upgrade the coal mines which supply it, the U.S. Ambassador announced in Sarajevo.

"This marks a new phase of reconstruction (in Bosnia). It will ensure that Sarajevo has electricity through the winter and will affect the lives of 850,000 people," U.S. Ambassador John Menzies said at the award-signing ceremony.
The project will pay for improvements to a coal-fired power plant in Kakanj and for upgrades in equipment at coal mines in central Bosnia on which the plant depends.
Work on the project is expected to be completed by the beginning of November.

The Kakanj plant is the main generator of electricity for central Bosnia. It is expected to provide a maximum of 110 megawatts of electricity for 850,000 people in the Zenica- Sarajevo region over the comming winter.
U.S. Presidential envoy Richard Sklar said the project showed how close cooperation between donors and Bosnian officials could result in timely benefits to the country's population.

"In the whole spectrum of international projects this year this is the largest single project of anyone, in any one package, in any field...This is the largest single integrated package being offered by anyone," Sklar said.

He explained that U.S. funds were being spent to rehabilitate generators at the Kakanj plant, to purchase new equipment for coal mines in central Bosnia and to support environmental protection measures in the region.
